panels.description: Track this for each Core cluster member. It will report 0 if it is not the leader and 1 if it is the leader. The sum of all of these should always be 1. However, there will be transient periods in which the sum can be more than 1 because more than one member thinks it is the leader.
panels.title: Leader

panels.description: The number of currently active transactions. Informational, not an indication of any issue. Spikes or large increases could indicate large data loads, or just high read load.
panels.title: Active transactions

panels.description: The total number of committed transactions. Informational, not an indication of any issue. Spikes or large increases indicate large data loads, or just high read load.
panels.title: Transactions committed

panels.description: The number of connections that are currently executing cypher and returning results.
panels.title: Running Bolt connection

panels.description: The total number of Bolt messages that have completed processing whether successfully or unsuccessfully in $interval. Useful for tracking overall load.
panels.title: Completed Bolt messages

panels.description: The total number of messages that have failed while processing in $interval. A high number of failures may indicate an issue with the server and further investigation of the logs is recommended.
panels.title: Failed Bolt messages

panels.description: The total number of page faults happened in the page cache. If this continues to rise over time, it could be an indication that more page cache is needed.
panels.title: Page cache faults

panels.description: Number of Bolt connections opened in $interval. This includes both successful and failed connections. Useful for monitoring load via the Bolt drivers in combination with other metrics.
panels.title: Bolt connections opened

panels.description: Total number of Bolt connections closed in $interval. This includes both properly and abnormally ended connections. Useful for monitoring load via Bolt drivers in combination with other metrics.
panels.title: Bolt connections closed

panels.description: The total number of Bolt connections that are not currently executing Cypher or returning results.
panels.title: Idle Bolt connections

panels.description: The number of connections that are currently executing cypher and returning results.
panels.title: Running Bolt connection

panels.description: The total number of Bolt messages that have completed processing whether successfully or unsuccessfully in $interval. Useful for tracking overall load.
panels.title: Completed Bolt messages

panels.description: The total number of messages that have failed while processing in $interval. A high number of failures may indicate an issue with the server and further investigation of the logs is recommended.
panels.title: Failed Bolt messages

panels.description: The proportion of time the JVM spends reclaiming the heap instead of doing other work. This metric can spike when the database is running low on memory. If this happens, it can halt processing and cause query execution errors.
panels.title: VM GC old generation

panels.description: The proportion of time the JVM spends reclaiming the heap instead of doing other work. This metric can spike when the database is running low on memory. If this happens, it can halt processing and cause query execution errors.
panels.title: VM GC young generation

panels.description: If Neo4j consistently uses 100% of the heap, increase the initial and max heap size.
panels.title: VM heap used

panels.description: Track this for each Core cluster member. It will report 0 if it is not the leader and 1 if it is the leader. The sum of all of these should always be 1. However, there will be transient periods in which the sum can be more than 1 because more than one member thinks it is the leader.
panels.title: Leader

panels.description: The commit index of the Raft log. Represents the commitment of previously appended entries. Its value increases monotonically if you do not unbind the cluster state. The commit index should always be bigger than or equal to the append index.
panels.title: Raft Delta (commit - applied)

panels.description: Delay between Raft message receive and process.
panels.title: Raft Processing Delay

panels.description: The total number of Raft replication requests attempts. It is bigger or equal than the replication requests.
panels.title: Raft replication attempts

panels.description: The total number of Raft replication attempts that have failed.
panels.title: Failed Raft replication attempts

panels.description: The total number of page faults happened in the page cache. If this continues to rise over time, it could be an indication that more page cache is needed.
panels.title: Page cache faults

panels.description: The ratio of number of used pages to total number of available pages. This metric shows what percentage of the allocated page cache is actually being used. If it is 100%, then it is likely that the hit ratio will start dropping, and you should consider allocating more RAM to page cache.
panels.title: Page cache usage ratio

panels.description: The ratio of hits to the total number of lookups in the page cache. Performance relies on efficiently using the page cache, so this metric should be in the 98-100% range consistently. If it is much lower than that, then the database is going to disk too often.
panels.title: Page cache hit ratio

panels.description: The total number of committed transactions. Informational, not an indication of any issue. Spikes or large increases indicate large data loads, or just high read load.
panels.title: Transactions committed

panels.description: The number of currently active transactions. Informational, not an indication of any issue. Spikes or large increases could indicate large data loads, or just high read load.
panels.title: Active transactions

panels.description: The highest peak of concurrent transactions. This is a useful value to understand. It can help you with the design for the highest load scenarios and whether the Bolt thread settings should be altered.
panels.title: Highest concurrent transactions

panels.description: Execution time in milliseconds of queries executed successfully.
panels.title: Query execution time distribution

panels.description: The duration, in milliseconds, of the last check point event. Checkpoints should generally take several seconds to several minutes. Long checkpoints can be an issue, as these are invoked when the database stops, when a hot backup is taken, and periodically as well. Values over 30 minutes or so should be cause for some investigation.
panels.title: Check point duration
